text: ... is this correct? `Qt_jll_jll.jl` ?

So older versions of Julia did not check certificate revocations. 1.6 does. Presumably you are behind a firewall, and the revocation server is blocked? One option would be disable host verification using <https://github.com/JuliaLang/NetworkOptions.jl#verify_host>

text: No, that's not the usage. The `verify_host` function is what Pkg uses to check if the host should be verified. you don't have to call it. The documentation of the function states how you can change the verification logic. (Admittedly, all of this is not very clear).... Anyways ...

elements.text: No, that's not the usage. The

function is what Pkg uses to check if the host should be verified. you don't have to call it. The documentation of the function states how you can change the verification logic. (Admittedly, all of this is not very clear).... Anyways ...

text: What you need to do is set, in your environment, `JULIA_SSL_NO_VERIFY_HOSTS=*.<http://githubusercontent.com|githubusercontent.com>`

elements.text: What you need to do is set, in your environment,

text: You can set this within Julia, before doing any pkg or downloads using  `julia> ENV[JULIA_NO_VERIFY_HOSTS] = ...`

elements.text: You can set this within Julia, before doing any pkg or downloads using

Once you set the environment, you should check that
```verify_host("<https://raw.githubusercontent.com>", "SSL")```
returns `false`
